data.title: NOT the Savory Orient anymore
data.text:
Three of us, habitues of Savory Orient, ate at the Savory BISTRO the other night.  What a disappointment!  The house special duck was over-done, the pad thai just okay, the soup mediocre, and the prawn dish had two under-cooked prawns.  That we were the only guests in the whole restaurant at dinner hour should have warned us.
I do hope the original Savory Orient returns.

data.title: Savory Orient has a new chef and is now Savory Orient Bistro
data.text:
While the decor is the same, the menu has changed. There are now French, Italian, and Moroccan dishes as well as Thai. (Yes, I know France is not "the Orient.") My review is mixed. The "wild mushroom" appetizer had very tame mushrooms - shitake and portabella, but was tasty in a tomato cream sauce. The main flavoring was ginger and pepper. I think a puff pastry would have been better than the filo sheet the chef chose to use. The duck in tamarind sauce was very good, cooked so there was no fat and the skin was crispy. Presentation was lovely and tamarind was an interesting variety for cherry or orange or apricot. Moroccan chicken didn't seem very Moraccan. The spices were very subtle. The shrimp and scallop dish was nothing special. Thai tapioca is less sweet than what Americans are used to, so it wasn't crazy to put coconut ice cream on it.
Service was very good. My favorite thing about this place is that - unlike so many restaurants today - you can actually hear the people on the other side of the table, and have a real conversation over dinner.

data.title: Thai Fusion
data.text: I had lunch there today. I found it online and was curious what fusion meant in San Rafael for Thailand. What I look for is layers of flavor and it needs to be above the norm. From being seated to leaving it took 45 minutes without dessert. Light room, not so busy. I got the lunch combo. Value here as you get soup, salad, and entre. The soup was a choice of two. I selected the lemon grass soup with coconut milk. Always refreshing. Standard in flavor. My server surprised me with a sample of the other ...an artichoke soup. I never had one before and it was very good. The salad was different as the Chef used a red wine vinegar which we don't see often. Also in my salad which I appreciated was a thin slice of red bell pepper for a burst of flavor and jicama. How nice to find the texture in my food. The entre was called Drunken Noodle. I had mine with chicken. The description said it was fettuccini which lead me to believe it was a wheat pasta. It was actually a chow fun or wide thick Chinese Rice Noodle. I prefer Chow Fun as it has a wonderful texture. As I was eating, I was looking for layers of flavor which would identify this as a bistro. Not just a one sauce flavored meal. I am happy to say, they were there. Subtle, but present. I could distinguish the aromatic herbs over the top and underneath. The sauces were light and noticeably lighter in salt. A blessing to many customers. Because this is fusion, don't expect the Thai fire and heat in the meal. Just enjoy the pleasant surroundings and your meal. Thank goodness they didn't over decorate. Enjoy. It was money well spent.

data.title: Asian food done right!
data.text:
My wife and I were in San Rafael in the springtime. We were walking the street fair that takes place every week, and we were getting hungry. We like Chinese cuisine so we went to Savory Orient on C street. Let me tell you the food was FANTASTIC! We have never tasted Asian food so good. We returned the next night (our last in town) and sampled additional dishes. Everything was fresh and very tasty. I commented to my wife that you could taste each individual item in the dishes. We cannot wait to go back, but since we live in Cleveland (which NO Asian restaurants here compare...) it is a bit difficult to get there...
HIGHLY RECOMENDED!

data.title: Best Asian food in Marin
data.text: We went for dinner.   Lots of parking across the street.  Interior was very nice. This restaurant has a very diverse asian food menu.  We liked the Korean Beef with Spinach and the Shanghai noodles.  It has the most interesting and unique asian food menu in Marin.  Food was delicious.

data.title: Pleasant Surprise
data.text: My wife and I wandered in here before heading to the Rafael theatre. Not knowing what to expect, we were pleasantly surprised to be served an excellent Thai meal. We started with a spicy and sour prawn soup with mushrooms and tomatoes in a light broth flavored with lemmon grass. Then I had a very nicely-prepared alaskan cod sauteed in a chilies/garlic/plum sauce and served with simple steamed vegetables on the side. My wife had the chicken daily special prepared with snow peas and asparagus. Everything was perfectly spiced with light, appealing sauces. We'll come back here again (for the food, not necessarily the atmosphere).

data.title: Business Lunch
data.text:
Food and service is consistently good. This place is a little off to the side on a side street so it doesn't seem to get very busy.

Their corn fritters (which are only at dinner) are amazing!

For lunch they have a special "lunch club" menu where you assemble your meal as you like from a series or courses.
